text:
Hi Arran,
My interview went well! I think it was because of how they arranged the day for us. When I came in at the reception I had to wait with 13 other students and then we went upstairs collectively where we were then greeted by one of the Architecture lecturer. He gave us a short presentation of what architecture is and what we will be learning at the uni etc. Then we had a tour of the campus and as we were walking around we got to talk to each other so we felt a little relaxed and then we came back and had a 5 min break while we talked to each other then 2-3 students were being called at a time
After talking to the others, I felt a lot more relaxed because we were all in the same situation and we reassured each other so that was nice.

My interview started positively, the interviewer said my personal statement was good/interesting and then I think he read my first paragraph wrong because he thought it was work experience I had and I told him the architect I mentioned was at a speaker series at school at the start of year 12 and I explained how that interested me

Then he asked to see my portfolio, I took out my art book first and I told him that I had only started Art in September because Geography clashed with Art so I couldn't attend my lessons and decided to do my Art in my free time

He said he was proud of me and told me how Art is important for Architecture, the history and stuff and then he commented on my subject choice for A Levels - Geography and Philosophy he thought were interesting

He asked what I learnt in Philosophy and I managed to relate some elements of it to Architecture, like thinking widely and deeply and the theories that make us consider others views which may be needed when creating something for 'people'

My portfolio was weak though. He looked through my art book and liked a few drawings but then it went downhill because I had a few incomplete work and not very high quality drawings. He asked me to show him something else, so I showed him my photography work which he liked because I had made sketches and paintings of buildings from it

My school reference about me was really good and I was predicted BBBB grades so he said he would give me a conditional offer because I seem hard working and enthusiastic about my education but he said I should really work on my portfolio and do a lot more architectural work and learn the history of buildings

Thank you so much for adding those questions, I'll try to come up with some answers. I had a look at the Westminster interview page and the youtube link, it was helpful and they've made it clear what kinds of things they're expecting from me at the interview.

I'm glad they've mentioned no CAD because Greenwich asked me for it and luckily I had my GCSE coursework on me (in case) and I showed it but he wanted something related to buildings - that would've been a lot of work to get done for my next interview

I really need to work on my drawings though, the other students brought in 3D models, amazing sketches of buildings and fancy portfolios with lots of work. They were advantaged for doing design based subjects

I asked the interviewer whether we will be doing a lot of group projects and he said no which surprised me because I assumed there would be something like that. He said we'll only have a little bit of it in the first year and then everything is independent. That is a question I'd also like to ask Westminster
Hope you're well now and thank you for helping me :slightly_smiling_face:
